choices.text: Propylthiouracil
Methimazole
Radioactive Iodine Ablation
Thyroidectomy

questions.text: Which of the following should be avoided in children with Graves disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Propylthiouracil

 

Option A:

 

Graves’ disease in children is usually managed initially with methimazole or carbimazole. Surgery or radioiodine may be indicated for severe or relapsing disease. Propylthiouracil is avoided in view of risk of hepatitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Methimazole: Preferred treatment in children with Graves disease.

 

Option C. Radioactive Iodine Ablation: Usually reserved for refractory/severe Graves disease in children.

 

Option D. Thyroidectomy: Usually reserved for refractory/severe Graves disease in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propylthiouracil should be avoided in children with Graves' disease due to the risk of hepatitis.

choices.text: Observation and repeat USG in 6 months
Fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNA)
Radioiodine scanning
Thyroid lobectomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a palpable thyroid nodule and has normal TSH levels. USG reveals a hypoechoic solid nodule with microcalcifications. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNA)

 

Option B:

 

TFT is usually normal in solitary nodules (and even in thyroid cancer). The presence of a hypoechoic solid nodule with microcalcifications on ultrasound raises suspicion for malignancy. FNA is the gold standard for evaluating thyroid nodules and is necessary to rule out cancer in this case.

 

High risk features in USG: Solid, Hypoechoic, Tall than wide, lobulated/irregular, extra-thyroidal extension, peripheral/rim or punctate/micro calcifications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Observation and repeat USG in 6 months: This approach is suitable for smaller or less suspicious nodules but not for those with high-risk features like microcalcifications. Delayed diagnosis could lead to potential complications if the nodule is malignant.

 

Option C. Radioiodine scanning: Useful only if hyperthyroid on TFTs.

 

Option D. Thyroid lobectomy: Surgery is usually reserved for confirmed malignancy or large symptomatic nodules. FNA is required for diagnosis before considering surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary thyroid cancer generally has a good prognosis, and its presence is not associated with a poor prognosis compared to other types of thyroid cancer.

choices.text: BRAF mutation is the most common genetic alteration
Lymph node micrometastases indicates poor prognosis.
It has a propensity to spread via the lymphatic system.
PTC is present in up to 25% of thyroid glands at autopsy

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is diagnosed with papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC). Which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lymph node micrometastases indicates poor prognosis.

 

Option B:

 

PTC usually spreads primarily via lymphatic system. Lymph node involvement is prognostic but micro metastases (< 2 mm) does not alter prognosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. BRAF mutation is the most common genetic alteration: True. a. BRAF V600E mutations reduce uptake of RAI and increase risk of recurrence (but effect on overall outcomes in unclear).

 

Option C. It has a propensity to spread via the lymphatic system: This is true. PTC has a tendency to spread to the lymph nodes in the neck.

 

Option D. PTC is present in up to 25% of thyroid glands at autopsy: This is also true. Many people have small, microscopic PTCs that never cause any problems.

 

Summary if important thyroid cancers:

 

  • PTC: Most common type of thyroid cancer (80-85% of differentiated thyroid cancers)
    • Genetics: RET/PTC rearrangements (20-40%), BRAF V600E mutation (most common), RAS mutations (20-30%).
  1. BRAF V600E mutations reduce uptake of RAI and increase risk of recurrence (but effect on overall outcomes in unclear).
  • Microscopic PTC is found in ∼25% of autopsy thyroids (clinically insignificant).
  • Characteristic cytological features: Orphan Annie eye appearance with Nuclear grooves and Prominent nucleoli.
  • Tall cell, columnar cell, hobnail, poorly differentiated – aggressive variants.
  • Can be multifocal & invade locally within the thyroid gland/ adjacent structures.
  • Usually Spreads primarily via lymphatic system.
  • Slow growth can lead to a significant burden of pulmonary metastases with few symptoms.
  • Lymph node involvement is prognostic but micro metastases (< 2 mm) does not alter prognosis. Most PTCs are identified in early stages (I or II) with excellent prognosis. Stage IV disease has markedly increased mortality but is rare (~1%).

 

  • FTC: more common in iodine-deficient regions.
    • Genetics: RAS mutations, PAX8-PPARγ1 rearrangement.
    • Diagnosis: Difficult by FNA alone, requires Bx to assess capsular/vascular invasion.
    • Prognosis:
  1. Capsular invasion only: Low risk of metastasis, lobectomy suffices.
  2. Angioinvasive FTC: More aggressive, can metastasize to bone, lung, and CNS.
  • Higher mortality than PTC, partly due to more frequent stage IV presentation.
  • Poor Prognostic Factors: Distant metastases, age >55 years, primary tumor size >4 cm, marked vascular invasion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymph node micrometastases (<2 mm) in papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) do not alter prognosis, even though lymph node involvement is prognostic.

choices.text: Thyroid dyshormonogenesis is the most common cause.
Most infants appear normal at birth.
The recommended initial dose of levothyroxine is 10-15 µg/kg/day.
Early treatment can significantly improve neurodevelopmental outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding congenital hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thyroid dyshormonogenesis is the most common cause.

 

Option A:

 

Most common cause is thyroid gland dysgenesis (65%), followed by Thyroid dyshormonogenesis (30%), and TSH-R antibody mediated (5%).

 

Most infants appear normal at birth. Permanent neurologic damage results if treatment is delayed. Cardiac problems are 4x more in congenital hypothyroidism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Most infants appear normal at birth: The majority of infants appear normal at birth (but classic features are prolonged jaundice, poor feeding, hypotonia, macroglossia, delayed bone maturation, and umbilical hernia).

 

Option C. The recommended initial dose of levothyroxine is 10-15 µg/kg/day: When the diagnosis is confirmed, T4 is instituted at a dose of 10–15 μg/kg/day and the dose is adjusted by close monitoring of TSH levels.

 

Option D. Early treatment can significantly improve neurodevelopmental outcomes: Early treatment with T4 results in normal IQ levels, but subtle neurodevelopmental abnormalities may occur in those with the most severe hypothyroidism at diagnosis or when treatment is delayed or suboptimal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid gland dysgenesis, not thyroid dyshormonogenesis, is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism.

choices.text: Associated with URI.
Elevated ESR.
Positive anti-TPO.
Giant cells in biopsy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a one-week history of fever, neck pain, and fatigue. On physical examination, her thyroid gland is tender. Thyroid function tests reveal elevated free T4 and suppressed TSH. Which of the following statements regarding her underlying condition is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Positive anti-TPO.

 

Option C:

 

The diagnosis is subacute (granulomatous) thyroiditis (a.k.a De Quervain’s thyroiditis).

 

Disease usually follows an URI and has a classic triphasic course (thyrotoxic → hypothyroid → resolution). ESR usually elevated and RAIU will be suppressed. TPO antibodies will usually test negative and biopsy typically shows patchy inflammation with granulomas and giant cells. Treatment is supportive (NSAIDs 1st line → Prednisolone in case of poor response).


Beta blockers can be used to abate thyrotoxic symptoms and anti-thyroid drugs have NO role. LT4 replacement may be needed if the hypothyroid phase is prolonged, but doses should be low enough (50–100 μg/d) to allow TSH-mediated recovery.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Associated with URI: This is a true statement, as De Quervain’s thyroiditis is often triggered by a viral infection.

 

Option B. Elevated ESR: This is also true due to the inflammatory process.

 

Option D. Giant cells in biopsy: This is the characteristic histological finding due to the presence of granulomas in De Quervain’s thyroiditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies are usually negative in subacute (De Quervain’s) thyroiditis, which is associated with an elevated ESR and giant cells in biopsy following an upper respiratory infection.

choices.text: Graves disease
Thyrotoxicosis factitia
Toxic Multinodular Goiter
Thyroiditis

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of palpitations and excessive sweating. Physical examination reveals a non-tender thyroid gland. Thyroid function tests show an elevated free T4 and suppressed TSH. Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scan is shown. Thyroglobulin levels are low. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyrotoxicosis factitia.

 

Option B:

 

The low RAIU and low thyroglobulin levels in case of thyrotoxicosis confirm that the thyroid gland is not producing excess hormone. Hence, the diagnosis of thyrotoxicosis factitial (exogenous thyroid hormone use).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Graves' disease: Graves' disease is an autoimmune condition causing hyperthyroidism. It typically presents with a diffuse goiter, increased RAIU, and high thyroglobulin levels.

 

Option C. Toxic Multinodular Goiter: This condition also has an increased RAIU and increased thyroglobulin levels.

 

Option D. Thyroiditis: RAIU can be suppressed but thyroglobulin levels are usually elevated in thyroiditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyrotoxicosis factitia is characterized by low radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) and low thyroglobulin levels, indicating exogenous thyroid hormone use.

choices.text: RAI therapy is ineffective in young patients.
The patient is experiencing a relapse of Graves' disease.
The patient is developing hypothyroidism.
The full effect of RAI therapy takes 2-3 months to manifest.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with Graves' disease undergoes RAI therapy. Two months later, she complains of persistent palpitations and heat intolerance. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her persistent symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The full effect of RAI therapy takes 2-3 months to manifest.

 

Option D:

 

It can take several weeks to months for RAI to fully destroy thyroid tissue and for symptoms to resolve.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. RAI therapy is ineffective in young patients: RAI is effective in all age groups.

 

Option B. The patient is experiencing a relapse of Graves' disease: Relapse is possible, but less likely within two months.

 

Option C. The patient is developing hypothyroidism:  Hypothyroidism is a later complication of RAI.

 

Summary of RAIA in Graves:

 

  • Indication: Initial treatment or for relapses after antithyroid drugs.
  • Tracer used: I131. Emits β & γ. t1/2 ∼ 8 days.
  • Elderly/Cardiac Patients: Consider pretreatment with antithyroid drugs and beta-blockers (because of small, increased risk of Thyrotoxic Crisis)
    • Carbimazole/Methimazole: Stop 2-3 days before and restart 3-7 days after RAI.
    • PTU: Prolonged radioprotective effect, requires longer discontinuation or higher RAI dose.
  • Persistence of Hyperthyroidism: Can persist for 2-3 months, managed with beta-blockers or antithyroid drugs.
  • Safety Precautions: Avoid close contact with children and pregnant women for 5-7 days.
  • Complications:
    • Radiation Thyroiditis: Mild pain may occur 1-2 weeks after treatment.
    • Flare of Orbitopathy: Especially in smokers. Consider prednisone pre-treatment.
    • Permanent Hypothyroidism: Risk is 10-20% in the first year, 5% per year thereafter, requiring lifelong LT4 replacement.
    • Possibly a small increased lifetime risk of solid cancers.
  • Contraindications: Pregnancy, breastfeeding and suspected thyroid cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The full effect of RAI therapy for Graves' disease takes 2-3 months to manifest, which can explain persistent symptoms shortly after treatment.

choices.text: Age < 50 is a risk factor
Long-term anticoagulation is unnecessary
Digoxin sensitivity is increased
Warfarin sensitivity is decreased

questions.text: A patient with thyrotoxicosis develops atrial fibrillation. Which of the following statements regarding their management is CORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Long-term anticoagulation is unnecessary

 

Option B:

 

Anticoagulation should be considered in all patients with AF and thyrotoxicosis. There is often spontaneous reversion to sinus rhythm with control of hyperthyroidism, and long-term anticoagulation is not usually required.

 

Decreased warfarin doses are required when patients are thyrotoxic (sensitivity increased as production of vitamin K dependent clotting factors are reduced).

 

If digoxin is used, increased doses are often needed in the thyrotoxic state (sensitivity decreased because of increased renal clearance and increased number of Na-K ATPse)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Age < 50 is a risk factor: Elderly patients (Age >50) are at increased risk.

 

Option C. Digoxin sensitivity is increased: Digoxin sensitivity is decreased because of increased renal clearance and increased number of Na-K ATPse.

 

Option D. Warfarin sensitivity is decreased: Warfarin sensitivity is increased as production of vitamin K dependent clotting factors are reduced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-term anticoagulation is generally unnecessary in patients with atrial fibrillation and thyrotoxicosis, as spontaneous reversion to sinus rhythm often occurs with control of hyperthyroidism.

choices.text: Give Levothyroxine 200µg IV STAT
Give Hydrocortisone 100mg IV STAT
Give Levothyroxine 200µg and 100mg Hydrocortisone IV STAT
Observation and repeat TFT after discharge

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with congestive heart failure and sepsis. Thyroid function tests (TFT) reveal a low total T3, normal free T4 and normal TSH. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Observation and repeat TFT after discharge

 

Option D:

 

The patient's presentation of low total T3, normal free T4, and normal TSH in the setting of congestive heart failure and sepsis is most consistent with sick euthyroid syndrome (SES). SES is a common finding in critically ill patients and is characterized by alterations in thyroid hormone levels without underlying thyroid disease (a.k.a Non Thyroidal Illness)

 

In SES, the conversion of T4 to T3 is often impaired, leading to low T3 levels. However, TSH and free T4 levels are usually normal, as seen in this case.

 

Management of SES: Observation and treat the underlying condition. Can repeat TFTs after recovery from illness if suspicious of underlying thyroid dysfunction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Give Levothyroxine 200µg IV STAT: Levothyroxine replacement is not indicated in SES and may even be harmful.

 

Option B. Give Hydrocortisone 100mg IV STAT: This could be appropriate for suspected adrenal insufficiency.

 

Option C. Give Levothyroxine 200µg and 100mg Hydrocortisone IV STAT: This could be an appropriate treatment for myxedema coma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with sick euthyroid syndrome, characterized by low total T3, normal free T4, and normal TSH in the context of critical illness, observation and repeat TFTs after recovery is the appropriate management.

choices.text: A-iv, B-iii, C-ii, D-i
A-iv, B-iii, C-i,D-ii
A-iii, B-iv, C-i,D-ii
A-iii, B-iv, C-ii,D-i

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-iv, B-iii, C-ii, D-i

 

Explanation:

 

  • If there is no residual thyroid function, the daily replacement dose of LT4 is usually 1.6 μg/kg body weight (typically 100–150 μg/d)
  • Adult patients under 60 years old without evidence of heart disease may be started on 50–100 μg of LT4 daily.
  • For adults with indications to treat in a subclinical hypothyroidism treatment is administered by starting with a low dose of LT4 (25–50 μg/d).
  • In the elderly, especially patients with known coronary artery disease, the starting dose of LT4 is 12.5–25 μg/d.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Standard Adult: 50-100 µg/day
  • Post thyroidectomy: 100-150 µg/day
  • Coronary Artery Disease: 12.5-25 µg/day
  • Subclinical Hypothyroidism: 25-50 µg/day

choices.text: Propranolol
Propylthiouracil (PTU)
Radioactive iodine (RAI)
Hydrocortisone

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of Graves' disease presents to the emergency department with fever, tachycardia, agitation, and vomiting. She recently underwent a dental procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for her suspected condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Propylthiouracil (PTU)

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with thyrotoxic crisis (thyroid storm), a life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism. PTU is the initial drug of choice due to its rapid onset of action and its ability to inhibit peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.

 

Mortality of thyroid storm is 30% even with therapy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Propranolol (A): Can be used for cardio-protection but not immediately required.

 

Option C. Radioactive iodine (C): Not suitable for acute management of thyrotoxic crisis.

 

Option D. Hydrocortisone (D): Adjunctive therapy in thyroid storm, can be added later.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the most appropriate initial treatment for thyrotoxic crisis (thyroid storm) due to its rapid onset of action and ability to inhibit peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.

choices.text: TPO and Tg antibodies in the mother can cause fetal hypothyroidism.
High Iodine intake increases the risk.
Thyroid destruction is primarily mediated by the CD8+ cytotoxic T cells.
Alcohol intake is protective.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Hashimoto’s thyroiditis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TPO and Tg antibodies in the mother can cause fetal hypothyroidism.

 

Option A:

 

Transplacental passage of Tg or TPO antibodies has no effect on the fetal thyroid (but transplacental passage of TSH-R blocking antibodies may induce transient neonatal hypothyroidism).

Genetic associations: HLA-DR3/DR4/DR5 & CTLA-4 (weak). Down’s and Turner’s syndrome patients are at increased risk as well.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. High Iodine intake increases the risk: A high iodine or low selenium intake and decreased exposure to microorganisms in childhood increases risk.

 

Option C. Thyroid destruction is primarily mediated by the CD8+ cytotoxic T cells: True. Pathogenic effect of antibodies is restricted to a secondary role in amplifying an ongoing autoimmune response.

 

Option D. Alcohol intake is protective: Smoking cessation transiently increases incidence, whereas alcohol intake seems protective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transplacental passage of Tg or TPO antibodies has no effect on the fetal thyroid, whereas TSH-R blocking antibodies may induce transient neonatal hypothyroidism.

choices.text: S. Tg is a sensitive marker post-surgery.
Universal Target TSH post-surgery is 0.5-2 mIU/L.
Patient should follow low Iodine diet for 1-2 weeks prior to I131 therapy.
TSH > 25 is required at the time of I131 therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding thyroid cancer treatment after thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Universal Target TSH post-surgery is 0.5-2 mIU/L.

 

Option B:

 

Target TSH post-surgery is based on the risk of recurrence.

 

  • Low risk of recurrence: 0.5–2.0 mIU/L
  • Intermediate risk of recurrence: 0.1–0.5 mIU/L
  • High risk of recurrence & metastatic disease: <0.1 mIU/L

 

I131 therapy: Low-iodine diet for 1–2 weeks before treatment and serum TSH must be >25 mIU/L at the time of therapy (usually achieved by thyroid hormone withdrawal or by rTSH injections). RAIA is not useful if tumour size < 2cm or 2-4 cm + low risk.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. S. Tg is a sensitive marker post-surgery: This is true. Serum thyroglobulin (Tg) is a useful tumor marker for monitoring patients with papillary and follicular thyroid cancers after thyroidectomy.

 

Option C. Patient should follow low Iodine diet for 1-2 weeks prior to I131 therapy: This is also true. A low iodine diet is recommended before radioactive iodine (RAI) therapy to enhance the uptake of iodine by any remaining thyroid tissue or cancer cells.

 

Option D. TSH > 25 is required at the time of I131 therapy: This is generally true for patients with high-risk thyroid cancer. A higher TSH level helps stimulate the uptake of RAI by thyroid cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The target TSH level post-surgery for thyroid cancer patients is based on the risk of recurrence, not universally 0.5-2 mIU/L. It ranges from 0.5-2.0 mIU/L for low risk, 0.1-0.5 mIU/L for intermediate risk, to <0.1 mIU/L for high risk or metastatic disease.

choices.text: De Quervain's thyroiditis
Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis
Riedel's thyroiditis
Hashimoto's thyroiditis

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician 6 months after delivery with complaints of fatigue, cold intolerance, and weight gain for the last 3 weeks. She also reports feeling depressed and having difficulty concentrating. Her thyroid function tests reveal elevated TSH and low free T4 levels and positive anti-TPO antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis

 

Option B:

 

The patient's postpartum presentation with a hypothyroid phase (fatigue, cold intolerance, weight gain, depression, elevated TSH, and low free T4) is characteristic of subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis, also known as painless thyroiditis. The presence of anti-TPO antibodies further supports this diagnosis, as it is an autoimmune condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. De Quervain's thyroiditis: This is a painful form of thyroiditis and they have an elevated ESR. Anti TPO antibodies are rarely positive in De Quervain’s.

 

Option C. Riedel's thyroiditis: This is a rare fibrotic thyroiditis with a hard, fixed goiter.

 

Option D. Hashimoto's thyroiditis: While also autoimmune, Hashimoto's typically presents with a gradual (chronic) onset of hypothyroidism and is less likely to occur postpartum.

 

Summary of post-partum thyroiditis:

 

  • Similar to De Quervain’s thyroiditis, but painless and have normal ESR.
  • Occurs in 5% of women 3-6 months postpartum, termed postpartum thyroiditis.
  • Associated with TPO antibodies antepartum, 3x more common in type 1 diabetes.
  • Recovery is the rule. Annual follow-up recommended as some develop permanent hypothyroidism. May recur in subsequent pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis, also known as painless thyroiditis, often presents postpartum with a hypothyroid phase and positive anti-TPO antibodies.

choices.text: Graves' disease
Toxic multinodular goiter
Subacute thyroiditis (de Quervain's thyroiditis)
TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with weight loss, heat intolerance, and palpitations. Her TSH is normal, and free T4 is elevated. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

 

Option D:

 

The combination of normal TSH, elevated free T4 is consistent with central hyperthyroidism.

 

TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma is the only cause of central hyperthyroidism in the list, but it is very rare.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Graves' disease: TSH would be suppressed as it is a primary hyperthyroidism. RAIU will show diffuse increase in uptake of Iodine.

 

Option B. Toxic multinodular goiter: TSH would be suppressed as it is a primary hyperthyroidism. RAIU will show patchy multi-focal increased uptake of Iodine.

 

Option C. Subacute thyroiditis (de Quervain's thyroiditis): TSH would be suppressed as it is a primary hyperthyroidism. RAIU will show decreased uptake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma is indicated by the combination of normal TSH and elevated free T4, consistent with central hyperthyroidism.

choices.text: Refetoff syndrome
TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma
McCune-Albright syndrome
Graves' disease

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with growth retardation, delayed bone age, and normal intellect. His thyroid function tests reveal elevated T3, T4, and normal TSH levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Refetoff syndrome

 

Option A:

 

Refetoff syndrome, also known as resistance to thyroid hormone (RTH), is a rare genetic disorder. TFTs would show central hyperthyroid picture. There are two types:

  • Generalised RTH: Clinically euthyroid/hypothyroid.
  • Pituitary RTH: Clinically thyrotoxic.

The patient in the vignette is likely to have Generalized RTH.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma: This would result in elevated TSH and T4 levels, but the patient would likely exhibit symptoms of hyperthyroidism.

 

Option C. McCune-Albright syndrome: This syndrome is associated with precocious puberty, bone lesions, and café-au-lait spots.

 

Option D. Graves' disease: This autoimmune disorder causes clinical hyperthyroidism with elevated T4 and suppressed TSH levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Refetoff syndrome, or resistance to thyroid hormone (RTH), presents with elevated T3 and T4, normal TSH levels, growth retardation, and delayed bone age, with the patient usually being clinically euthyroid or hypothyroid.

choices.text: Alopecia
Amenorrhea
Carpal tunnel syndrome
Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of fatigue and constipation. Thyroid function tests show reduced free T4 and increased TSH levels. Which of the following symptoms or signs is LEAST likely to be associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cardiac tamponade

 

Option D:

 

The clinical presentation and lab results are consistent with primary hypothyroidism.

 

Pericardial effusion occurs in 30% patients but cardiac tamponade is an unlikely event.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alopecia: Hypothyroidism can cause hair loss due to slowed metabolism and decreased hair growth.

 

Option B. Amenorrhea: Hypothyroidism can disrupt menstrual cycles (Menorrhagia initially and oligo/amenorrhea in long standing disease).

 

Option C. Carpal tunnel syndrome: Hypothyroidism can cause fluid retention and swelling, which can compress the median nerve in the wrist, leading to carpal tunnel syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac tamponade is the least likely symptom associated with primary hypothyroidism, despite pericardial effusion being relatively common.

choices.text: Ask her to review immediately to the hospital
Ask her to take 2 tablets today
Skip the missed dose and resume from today
Ask her to take TFT and review

questions.text: A 45-year-old hypothyroid patient calls your OPD and informs that she has missed her thyroxine tablet the previous day and asks what to do about it. What will be your advice?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ask her to take 2 tablets today

 

Option B:

 

Because T4 has a long half-life (7 days), patients who miss a dose can be advised to take two doses of the skipped tablets at once.

 

Explanation:

 

All others are incorrect by default.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Advise hypothyroid patients who miss a dose of thyroxine to take two doses the next day due to the long half-life of T4.

choices.text: Levothyroxine 200 μg IV bolus
IV Hydrocortisone 50mg 6th hourly
IV broad spectrum Antibiotics
External Rewarming

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis is brought to the emergency department with altered mental status, hypothermia (35°C), bradycardia (45 bpm), and hypotension (80/50 mmHg). Her skin is dry and doughy, and she has non-pitting edema in her extremities. Which of the following is the NOT indicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) External Rewarming

 

Option D:

 

Blankets (passive warming) can be used to prevent heat loss in myxedema coma but external (active) warming is indicated only if the temperature is <30°C, as it can result in cardiovascular collapse.

 

Mortality in myxedema coma is 20-40% despite appropriate treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Levothyroxine 200 μg IV bolus: LT4 single IV bolus of 200–400 μg (loading dose) is the preferred initial treatment in myxedema coma (alternate if no IV avaialble: NG tube LT4).

 

Option B. IV Hydrocortisone 50mg 6th hourly: Parenteral hydrocortisone (50 mg every 6 h) should be administered because there is impaired adrenal reserve in profound hypothyroidism

 

Option C. IV broad spectrum Antibiotics: Sepsis is an important precipitating cause of myxedema coma. Early use of broad-spectrum antibiotics is warranted until infection is excluded.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External (active) rewarming is not indicated for myxedema coma unless the temperature is below 30°C, as it can result in cardiovascular collapse.

choices.text: Sinus Tachycardia
Polyuria
Hypercalcemia
Hypocalciuria

questions.text: All of the following are features of thyrotoxicosis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypocalciuria

 

Option D:

 

Hypercalciuria is common in thyrotoxicosis (may be because of underlying hypercalcemia which is seen in 20% cases). This is due to direct effect of thyroid hormones on bone resorption (which can lead to osteopenia in longstanding thyrotoxicosis).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sinus Tachycardia: The most common CV manifestation in thyrotoxicosis is sinus tachycardia.  Atrial fibrillation is more common in patients >50 years of age.

 

Option B. Polyuria: Probably due to increased renal blood flow and hypercalciuria.

 

Option C. Hypercalcemia: This is due to the effect of thyroid hormones causing bone resorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypercalciuria, not hypocalciuria, is a common feature of thyrotoxicosis due to the effect of thyroid hormones on bone resorption.

choices.text: MRI of the orbit
X-ray of hands with wrist
CT of the chest
Repeat TFT

questions.text: A 54-year-old male smoker with a history of Graves' disease presents with weight loss and loss of appetite. He is on carbimazole 5mg per day, and his recent free T4 levels (done a week ago) were normal. He has mild orbitopathy but no dermopathy. On examination, you notice clubbing; otherwise, he is vitally stable. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT of the chest

 

Option C:

 

The presence of clubbing in a smoker, especially with new-onset weight loss and loss of appetite, raises a high suspicion of underlying lung malignancy. Even though his thyroid function tests were normal a week ago, the concerning finding of clubbing necessitates further investigation to rule out a serious underlying condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MRI of the orbit: It not the primary concern given the new symptoms and clubbing.

 

Option B. X-ray of hands with wrist: May be useful in thyroid acropachy (It refers to a form of clubbing found in < 1% of patients with Graves’ disease. It is so strongly associated with thyroid dermopathy that an alternative cause of clubbing should be sought in a Graves’ patient without coincident skin and orbital involvement).

 

Option D. Repeat TFT: Repeating thyroid function tests is unlikely to yield new information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a smoker with Graves' disease presenting with clubbing, weight loss, and loss of appetite, a CT of the chest is indicated to rule out an underlying lung malignancy.

choices.text: Poor intrauterine growth
Fetal tachycardia
Reduced Bone Age
Fetal goiter

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely in a case of neonatal thyrotoxicosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reduced Bone Age

 

Option C:

 

Transplacental transfer of antibodies (from mother with Graves) can cause fetal or neonatal thyrotoxicosis. Features include Poor intrauterine growth, a fetal heart rate of >160 beats/min, advanced (not reduced) bone age, fetal goiter. Risk increases substantially if the antibody levels (especially ≥ 26 weeks) are 3x higher than the normal range.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Poor intrauterine growth: Common feature due to increased basal metabolic rate in the fetus with thyrotoxicosis.

 

Option C. Fetal tachycardia: HR > 160/min is commin in the fetus with thyrotoxicosis.

 

Option D. Fetal goiter: Common due to trophic effects of antibodies on the thyroid gland. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal thyrotoxicosis is associated with advanced bone age, not reduced bone age.

choices.text: Multiple sclerosis
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML)
Hashimoto's encephalopathy
Neurosarcoidosis

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with progressive confusion, memory loss, and seizures. She also has a history of hypothyroidism and she is on Levothyroxine 75 µg/d. Her records suggest a high anti TPO antibodies and MRI of the brain reveals diffuse white matter hyperintensities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hashimoto's encephalopathy

 

Option C:

 

Hashimoto's encephalopathy (HE), also known as steroid-responsive encephalopathy associated with autoimmune thyroiditis (SREAT), fits this clinical picture. The patient's history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis, along with the cognitive decline, seizures, and white matter changes on MRI, strongly suggest HE.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multiple sclerosis (MS): MS follows dissemination in space and time and it is not associated with anti TPO antibodies.

 

Option B. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML): It is caused by JC virus and is usually seen in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Neurosarcoidosis: The clinical features are NOT compatible with the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hashimoto's encephalopathy, also known as steroid-responsive encephalopathy associated with autoimmune thyroiditis (SREAT), is characterized by progressive confusion, memory loss, seizures, high anti-TPO antibodies, and diffuse white matter hyperintensities on MRI.

choices.text: Lymphocytic infiltration
Atrophy of thyroid follicles
Absence of fibrosis
Goiter

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with severe fatigue. Thyroid function tests reveal low free T4, high TSH, and elevated anti-TPO antibodies. Which of the following statements regarding the histopathological findings in her thyroid gland is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Absence of fibrosis

 

Option C:

 

The patient's clinical presentation and laboratory results are consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Histopathological findings are lymphocytic infiltration (can form germinal centres), atrophy of thyroid follicles and fibrosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lymphocytic infiltration: Hallmark of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis and can form germinal centres within the gland.

 

Option B. Atrophy of thyroid follicles: The destruction of thyroid follicles by the immune system leads to their shrinkage and atrophy.

 

Option D. Goiter: In the early stages of Hashimoto's, the thyroid gland may become enlarged (goiter) due to inflammation. However, as the disease progresses, the gland can shrink due to atrophy. Atrophy is especially common in Asians.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis histopathology includes lymphocytic infiltration, atrophy of thyroid follicles, and fibrosis.

choices.text: Start treatment with levothyroxine
Initiate radioactive iodine therapy
Perform open biopsy for definitive diagnosis
Begin glucocorticoid therapy

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a firm, non-tender, fixed goiter and complaints of difficulty swallowing and hoarseness. Fine needle aspiration is inconclusive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perform open biopsy for definitive diagnosis

 

Option C:

 

The patient's clinical presentation of a firm, painless, fixed goiter with compressive symptoms (dysphagia, hoarseness) is highly suggestive of Riedel's thyroiditis. An open biopsy is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and rule out malignancy, which can present with similar features. FNA is often inconclusive in Riedel’s thyroiditis.

 

There is an association between Riedel’s thyroiditis and IgG4-related disease causing idiopathic fibrosis at other sites (retroperitoneum, mediastinum, biliary tree, lung, and orbit).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Start treatment with levothyroxine: Levothyroxine is used to treat hypothyroidism, which is uncommon (TFT is often normal) in Riedel's thyroiditis.

 

Option B. Initiate radioactive iodine therapy: Radioactive iodine therapy is used to treat hyperthyroidism, not indicated in this case.

 

Option D. Begin glucocorticoid therapy: Glucocorticoids may be considered after a definitive diagnosis of Riedel's thyroiditis is established, but not as the initial step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perform an open biopsy for a definitive diagnosis in a patient with a firm, non-tender, fixed goiter and compressive symptoms, as this presentation is highly suggestive of Riedel's thyroiditis.

choices.text: Potassium perchlorate
High-dose antithyroid drugs
Glucocorticoids (prednisone)
Thyroidectomy

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation treated with amiodarone presents with weight loss, palpitations, and heat intolerance. Thyroid function tests reveal suppressed TSH and elevated free T4. Thyroid USG shows decreased vascularity. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glucocorticoids (prednisone)

 

Option C:

 

The patient has amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis (AIT) type 2, characterized by destructive thyroiditis (decreased vascularity on ultrasound). Glucocorticoids are the first-line treatment for this type.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Potassium perchlorate: Used in type 1 AIT (increases synthesis, increased vascularity).

 

Option B. High-dose antithyroid drugs: Also used in type 1 AIT, ineffective in type 2 due to the release of preformed hormone.

 

Option D. Thyroidectomy: Reserved for severe, unresponsive cases, not the initial approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucocorticoids (prednisone) are the first-line treatment for amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis (AIT) type 2, characterized by destructive thyroiditis and decreased vascularity on ultrasound.

choices.text: Male gender
Age > 65 years
Papillary histology
p53 mutations

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with a rapidly enlarging neck mass and hoarseness. Fine needle aspiration biopsy reveals thyroid cancer. Which of the following factors is NOT associated with a poor prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Papillary histology

 

Option C:

 

Papillary thyroid cancer is the most common type of thyroid cancer and generally has a good prognosis, even in older patients. The presence of papillary histology would NOT be associated with a poor prognosis in this scenario.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Male gender: Male gender is associated with a worse prognosis in thyroid cancer compared to female gender.

 

Option B. Age > 65 years: Older age at diagnosis is a significant risk factor for poorer outcomes in thyroid cancer.

 

Option D. p53 mutations: p53 mutations are associated with a more aggressive tumor behavior and a poorer prognosis in thyroid cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary histology in thyroid cancer is not associated with a poor prognosis and generally indicates a good outcome.
